lg.l: Neglectis urenda filix innascitur agris. ·····Hor.
Perit, quod fucis ingrato.Vetus adagium---
A MAN with Expence and infinite Toil,
By Dunging and Planting, enabled his Soil;
With Trees of the best, the taste to Invite,
With uniform order that courted the sight:
No degenerate Weed the rich Ground did produce,
But all things afforded both Beauty and Use;
'Till from Dunghill transplanted, whilst yet but a seed,
A Nettle rear'd up its inglorious head;
The Gardner wou'd wisely have rooted it up,
To stop the Increase of a barbarous Crop:
But the Master forbad him, and after the Fashion
Of foolish good Nature, and blind Moderation,
Forbore him through pity, and chose it much rather,
To ask him some questions first, how he came hither?
`Kind sir, (quoth the Nettle) a Stranger I come,
`So Conscience compell'd me, to relinquish my Home,
`'Cause I wou'd not subscribe to a Mystery dark,
`That the Prince of all Trees, was the Jesuits Bark;
`An erroneous Tenet; I am sure, Sir, that you,
`No more than myself, will allow to be true:
`To you I for Refuge and Sanctuary sue,
`There's none so renown'd for Compassion, as you;
`And, tho' in some things, I differ from these:
`The rest of your Fruits, and beautiful Trees
`There's Digging and Dunging, my Nature much harms,
`And I cannot comply with your Garden Forms;
`Yet I and my Family, after our Fashion,
`Will peaceably stick to our own Education.
`Be pleas'd to allow them a place for to rest them,
`For the rest of your Trees, we'll never molest 'em;
`A kind Favour to us, and Protection afford,
`We'll do you no harm, Sir, I'll give you my word.
The good Man was soon won with this plausible Tale, Thus Fraud o'er good Nature, do's often prevail;
He welcomes his Guest, gives him free Toleration,
In the midst of his Garden, to take up his station;
And into his Breast do's his Enemy bring,
He never suspected the Nettle cou'd sting;
'Till flush'd with success, and of strength to be fear'd,.
Around him a num'rous Off-spring appear'd
The Master grew sensible what he had done,
And fain wou'd have had this new Guest to be gone;
But now 'twas too late, to bid him turn out,
A well-rooted Possession already was got:
The old Trees decay'd, and in their room grew,A stubborn, pestilent, poisonous Crew;
The Master, who first, the young Brood had admitted,Th' ungratefully stung him, and left him unpitied;
No help from Manuring and Planting was found,
'Till Weeds had eat-out the very heart of the Ground:
All Weeds they let in, and none are rejected,
In the room of the Cedar, the Brambles Elected:
Thus one Nettle uncropt, increase to such store,
There is nothing but Weeds, where were Flowers before.
The Moral.
Ingratitude, the blackest Evil, Quaere therefore, good Reader, are not,?
Was first invented by the Devil;
His power was by Heaven given,
And he employ'd it against Heaven:
Too many Devils now Incarnate
